page.title: 08West Wratting Area Farming
page.content: 1985 has been a very wet year for this part of the country and the farmers have also had to contend with a cold spring and cool summer . Consequently, the harvest of all crops is late, by about three weeks . There has been more disease on the crops than normal. Yields are as much as 30% down on the 1984 figure in some fields. Quite a lot of the barley and winter wheat were dashed down be exceptionally heavy rain in June, and a recorded two and threequarter inches of hail and rain fell in the afternoon of 17th June, causing much damage and concern. As a result of this, there was regrowth in the fields and later the weeds also grew through the flattened cereal stalks. However, the modern combine harvester, with a careful hand on the controls, can pick up the laying crop. (See slide)
